DataElement.preferredName: Bowel Patient Routine Activity Assessment Grade
DataElement.preferredDefinition: a description of the qualitative level of change in usual or habitual behavior or level of being active as a measure to evaluate the function of the digestive tract.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: related to the examination of an individual to evaluate the function of the digestive tract with regard to perceived changes in usual or habitual behavior or level of being active.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: (in-TES-tin) The long, tube-shaped organ in the abdomen that completes the process of digestion. There is both a large intestine and a small intestine. Also called the bowel.:A person who requires medical care.

Concepts.definition: The portion of the gastrointestinal tract between the stomach and the anus. It includes the small intestine and large intestine.
A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.

Property.preferredDefinition: An unvarying or habitual method or procedure.:The state of being active; any specific activity.:Examination of the body by auscultation, palpation, percussion, inspection, and olfaction.  (Taber's)

Concepts.definition: An unvarying or habitual method or procedure.
An active process; excludes processes and mechanisms which fulfill biological functions.

A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: information on quality of patient life and ability to function

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Describes how closely a cancer resembles normal tissue of its same type, and the cancer's probable rate of growth

Concepts.definition: The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.
